senses.definition: used as the subject of a verb when the speaker or writer is referring to himself/herself

examples.en: I think I'd better go now.
When they asked me if I wanted the job, I said yes.
He and I are old friends.
I'm not going to fall, am I?
I'm taller than her, aren't I?
Jen and I went to London yesterday.

senses.definition: interactive (= allowing information to be passed continuously and in both directions between a device or piece of software and the person who uses it)

examples.en: The Oxford iWriter teaches you how to plan and write essays.

senses.definition: the 9th letter of the English alphabet

examples.en: ‘Island’ begins with (an) I/‘I’.

idioms.word: dot your i’s and cross your t’s

senses.definition: to pay attention to the small details when you are finishing a task
the number 1 in Roman numerals
(especially on maps) Island(s); isle
water that has frozen and become solid

examples.en: There was ice on the windows.
The lake was covered with a sheet of ice.
the body of a man perfectly preserved in a block of ice
My hands are as cold as ice.
substantial loss of sea ice in the Arctic Ocean

senses.definition: a frozen surface that people skate on

examples.en: Both teams are on the ice, waiting for the whistle.
The dancers came out onto the ice.
People were skating on the ice.
They held hands as they glided across the ice.

senses.definition: a piece of ice used to keep food and drinks cold

examples.en: I'll have lemonade please—no ice.
a glass of water with ice and lemon
She ordered a vodka and ice.
The glass was filled with green liquid and crushed ice.

senses.definition: an ice cream

examples.en: Drinks, ices and popcorn are all on sale in the foyer.

senses.definition: a type of sweet food that consists of ice that has been crushed (= broken into very small pieces) and given a sweet taste
to be taking a risk
to say or do something that makes people feel more relaxed, especially at the beginning of a meeting, party, etc.

examples.en: Jim organized a few party games to break the ice when people first arrived.

senses.definition: to have no influence or effect on somebody

examples.en: His excuses cut no ice with me.

senses.definition: kept cold by being surrounded by ice

examples.en: All the food is laid out and the champagne is on ice.

senses.definition: not being dealt with now; waiting to be dealt with at a later time

examples.en: We've had to put our plans on ice for the time being.

senses.definition: performed by skaters on an ice rink

examples.en: Cinderella on ice

senses.definition: to cover a cake with icing
(in a mobile phone contact list) in case of emergency (= the name and number of a person to contact if you are ill, you have an accident, etc.)

examples.en: You should make sure that you have an ICE number stored in your phone.

senses.definition: a small symbol on a computer or smartphone screen that represents a program or a file

examples.en: Click on the printer icon with the mouse.
Tap the app icon on your phone to open it.

senses.definition: a famous person or thing that people admire and see as a symbol of a particular idea, way of life, etc.

examples.en: Madonna and other pop icons of the 1980s
a feminist/gay icon (= somebody that feminists/gay people admire)
Sandra has become a style icon, for the fashion world particularly.

senses.definition: a painting or statue of a holy person that is also thought of as a holy object
the part of the unconscious mind where many of a person’s basic needs, feelings and desires are supposed to exist
an official way of showing who you are, for example a document with your name, date of birth and often a photograph on it (the abbreviation for ‘identity’ or ‘identification’)

examples.en: You must carry ID at all times.
The police checked IDs at the gate.
You will need some form of photo ID.

senses.definition: identification (= the fact of showing, proving or recognizing who or what somebody/something is)

examples.en: The police need a witness to make a positive ID.

senses.definition: to identify somebody, usually a criminal or a dead body

examples.en: The police haven’t yet managed to ID the suspect.

senses.definition: to ask somebody to show a document that shows proof of their name, age, etc.

examples.en: The security guards ID’d everyone at the entrance to the festival.

senses.definition: one of the two main Muslim festivals, either Id ul-Fitr /iːd ʌl fɪtə(r)/ at the end of Ramadan, or Id ul-Adha /iːd ʌl ʌdə/, which celebrates the end of the pilgrimage to Mecca and Abraham’s sacrifice of a sheep
a plan, thought or suggestion, especially about what to do in a particular situation

examples.en: It would be a good idea to call before we leave.
That's a great idea!
I’ve had a brilliant idea!
I knew this was a bad idea.
The party's latest big idea is to create a Centre for Teaching Excellence.
The surprise party was Jane's idea.
He already had an idea for his next novel.
We’re having a meeting to try to come up with ideas for fundraising.
The idea of a new museum was first discussed two years ago.
I like the idea of living on a boat.
We've been toying with the idea of (= thinking about) getting a dog.
Her family expected her to go to college, but she had other ideas.
I don't know what to do, but I'm open to ideas.
It might be an idea (= it would be sensible) to try again later.
It seemed like a good idea at the time, and then it all went horribly wrong.
Ben is the ideas man and the others do the day-to-day work.
Ben is the idea man.

senses.definition: a picture or an impression in your mind of what somebody/something is like

examples.en: The brochure should give you a good idea of the hotel.
I had some idea of what the job would be like.
This film changed the very idea of what an outer space movie could be.
An evening at home watching TV is not my idea of a good time.
If this is your idea of a joke, then I don’t find it very funny.
I don't want anyone getting the wrong idea (= getting the wrong impression about something).

senses.definition: an opinion or a belief about something

examples.en: the experiences that shaped her ideas
He has some very strange ideas about education.
Her ideas on the family are pretty old-fashioned.
These photographs challenge conventional ideas of beauty.
She rejects the idea that product quality has suffered.

senses.definition: a feeling that something is possible or is true

examples.en: Where on earth did you get that idea?
What gave you the idea that he'd be here?
I have a pretty good idea where I left it—I hope I'm right.

senses.definition: the aim or purpose of something

examples.en: You'll soon get the idea (= understand).
What's the idea of the game?
The whole idea of going was so that we could meet her new boyfriend.

examples.cf: with the idea of doing something
examples.en: They buy other people's tickets with the idea of reselling them.

senses.definition: to start behaving in a more acceptable way, so that work gets done better, etc.

idioms.word: give somebody ideas | put ideas into somebody’s head

senses.definition: to give somebody hopes about something that may not be possible or likely; to make somebody act or think in an unreasonable way

examples.en: Who's been putting ideas into his head?

idioms.word: have no idea | not have the faintest, first, etc. idea

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you do not know something

examples.en: ‘What's she talking about?’ ‘I've no idea.’
He hasn't the faintest idea how to manage people.
I had no idea she’d had such a difficult life.
I don’t have any idea where he is.
She doesn't seem to have any idea of what I'm talking about.
I haven't got the faintest idea what she meant.
He hadn't had the slightest idea about what had been going on.

senses.definition: to have found a very good or successful way of living, doing something, etc.

examples.en: He's certainly got the right idea—retiring at 55.
The party had the right idea, but failed to win over the voters.

senses.definition: used to reply in a positive way to a suggestion that somebody has made

examples.en: Hey, that's an idea! And we could get a band, as well.

senses.definition: used to encourage people and to tell them that they are doing something right

examples.en: That's the idea! You're doing fine.

senses.definition: used to show that something is hard for somebody else to imagine

examples.en: You've no idea how much traffic there was tonight.

senses.definition: perfect; most suitable

examples.en: an ideal location/place
This beach is ideal for children.
She's the ideal candidate for the job.
The trip to Paris will be an ideal opportunity to practise my French.
The prime minister admitted the current situation was ‘not ideal’ (= was bad).
It was not the ideal solution to the problem.
Harvesting is being done in less than ideal conditions.

senses.definition: existing only in your imagination or as an idea; not likely to be real

examples.en: the search for ideal love

senses.definition: used to say that something is what you would like to happen or what should happen, but you know it cannot

examples.en: In an ideal world we would be recycling and reusing everything.

senses.definition: an idea or standard that seems perfect, and worth trying to achieve or obtain

examples.en: He was accused of betraying his political ideals.
She found it hard to live up to his high ideals.
advancing the ideals of freedom and democracy

senses.definition: a person or thing that you think is perfect

examples.en: It's my ideal of what a family home should be.
This agreement falls far short of the ideal.

senses.definition: similar in every detail

examples.en: a row of identical houses
The two pictures are similar, although not identical.
Her dress is almost identical to mine.
The name on the ticket should be identical with the one in the passport.

senses.definition: the same

examples.en: This is the identical room we stayed in last year.

senses.definition: the process of showing, proving or recognizing who or what somebody/something is

examples.en: The identification of the crash victims was a long and difficult task.
Accurate identification of these birds is difficult.
Each product has a number for easy identification.
The vehicle's identification number is stamped on the engine.
Biometric identification methods include fingerprints and facial recognition scanners.
Only one witness could make a positive identification.
The hospital had mixed up the patients' identification tags.

senses.definition: the process of recognizing that something exists, or is important

examples.en: The early identification of children with special educational needs is very important.

senses.definition: official papers or a document that can prove who you are

examples.en: Can I see some identification, please?
To vote, Florida law requires a photo identification with a signature.

senses.definition: a strong feeling of sympathy, understanding or support for somebody/something

examples.en: her emotional identification with the play’s heroine
their increasing identification with the struggle for independence

senses.definition: the process of making a close connection between one person or thing and another

examples.en: the voters’ identification of the Democrats with high taxes

senses.definition: to recognize somebody/something and be able to say who or what they are

examples.en: She was able to identify her attacker.
Passengers were asked to identify their own suitcases before they were put on the plane.
Many of those arrested refused to identify themselves (= would not say who they were).
The bodies were identified as those of two suspected terrorists.
two species of waterbirds that can be identified by their distinctive beaks

senses.definition: to find or discover somebody/something

examples.en: First of all we must identify the problem areas.
Scientists have identified the gene responsible for the disease.
As yet they have not identified a buyer for the company.
to identify a need/factor/source/cause
They are trying to identify what is wrong with the present system.

senses.definition: to make it possible to recognize who or what somebody/something is

examples.en: In many cases, the clothes people wear identify them as belonging to a particular social class.
a serial number that uniquely identifies the disk

senses.definition: who or what somebody/something is

examples.en: The police are trying to discover the identity of the killer.
to establish/reveal/confirm the identity of somebody/something
Their names have been changed for the purposes of this article to protect their identities.
Their identities were kept secret.
Do you have any proof of identity?
The thief used a false identity.
He falls in love with her but can't reveal his true identity.
Each object in the collection has a unique identity number.
She went through an identity crisis in her teens (= was not sure of who she was or of her place in society).

senses.definition: the characteristics, feelings or beliefs that make people different from others

examples.en: national/cultural/personal identity
ethnic/racial identity
The region's sense of identity remained strong.
a plan to strengthen the corporate identity of the company
Scotland has never lost its identity as a separate nation.
She was searching for a clearer conception of her identity as a writer.

senses.definition: the state or feeling of being very similar to and able to understand somebody/something

examples.en: The two companies started working together as a result of a clear identity of interests.
He feels a strong sense of identity with his fellow soldiers.
There's a close identity between fans and their team.

senses.definition: based on or connected with an ideology

examples.en: ideological differences
This was rejected for ideological reasons.
His agenda has been purely ideological.

senses.definition: a set of ideas that an economic or political system is based on

examples.en: Marxist/capitalist ideology

senses.definition: a set of beliefs, especially one held by a particular group, that influences the way people behave

examples.en: the ideology of gender roles
alternative ideologies

senses.definition: a rude way to refer to somebody who you think is very stupid

examples.en: When I lost my passport, I felt such an idiot.
What idiot pressed the switch?

senses.definition: a word for a person with very low intelligence that is now considered offensive
used to say that one thing can, will or might happen or be true, depending on another thing happening or being true

examples.en: If you see him, give him this note.
I'll only stay if you offer me more money.
If necessary I can come at once.
You can stay for the weekend if you like.
If anyone calls, tell them I'm not at home.
If he improved his IT skills, he'd (= he would) easily get a job.
You would know what was going on if you'd (= you had) listened.
They would have been here by now if they'd caught the early train.
If I was in charge, I'd do things differently.
If I were in charge…

senses.definition: when; whenever; every time

examples.en: If metal gets hot it expands.
She glares at me if I go near her desk.

senses.definition: used after ask, know, find out, wonder, etc. to introduce one of two or more possibilities

examples.en: Do you know if he's married?
I wonder if I should wear a coat or not.
He couldn't tell if she was laughing or crying.
Listen to the tune and see if you can remember the words.

senses.definition: used after verbs or adjectives expressing feelings

examples.en: I am sorry if I disturbed you.
I'd be grateful if you would keep it a secret.
Do you mind if I turn the TV off?

senses.definition: used to admit that something is possible, but to say that it is not very important

examples.en: If she has any weakness, it is her Italian.
So what if he was late. Who cares?

senses.definition: used to ask somebody to listen to your opinion

examples.en: If you ask me, she's too scared to do it.
If you think about it, those children must be at school by now.
If you remember, Mary was always fond of animals.

senses.definition: used before an adjective or adverb to introduce a contrast

examples.en: He's a good driver, if a little over-confident.
We'll only do it once—if at all.

senses.definition: used with will or would to ask somebody politely to do something

examples.en: If you will sit down for a few moments, I'll tell the manager you're here.
If you would care to leave your name, we'll contact you as soon as possible.

senses.definition: used before could, may or might to suggest something or to interrupt somebody politely

examples.en: If I may make a suggestion, perhaps we could begin a little earlier next week.

senses.definition: despite the possibility that; no matter whether

examples.en: I'll get there, even if I have to walk.

senses.definition: despite the fact that; even though

examples.en: He is a great leader, even if he has many enemies.

senses.definition: used to say something about an event that may or may not happen

examples.en: If and when we ever meet again I hope he remembers what I did for him.

senses.definition: used to express an opinion about something, or after a negative statement to suggest that the opposite is true

examples.en: I'd say he was more like his father, if anything.
She's not thin—if anything she's on the plump side.

senses.definition: used to give somebody advice

examples.en: If I were you I'd start looking for another job.

senses.definition: used to introduce a different suggestion, after a sentence with if

examples.en: I'll go if you're going. If not (= if you are not), I'd rather stay at home.

senses.definition: used after a yes/no question to say what will or should happen if the answer is ‘no’

examples.en: Are you ready? If not, I'm going without you.
Do you want that cake? If not, I'll have it.

senses.definition: used to suggest that something may be even larger, more important, etc. than was first stated

examples.en: They cost thousands if not millions of pounds to build.

senses.definition: used to say that you wish something was true or that something had happened

examples.en: If only I were rich.
If only I knew her name.
If only he'd remembered to send that letter.
If only I had gone by taxi.

senses.definition: if that is the case

examples.en: Do you do research in your studies? If so, what research methods do you use?

senses.definition: used to say that something that is happening is surprising

examples.en: I'm surprised they've invited me to their wedding—it's not as if I know them well.

senses.definition: used to state the only situation in which something can happen

examples.en: Only if a teacher has given permission is a student allowed to leave the room.
Only if the red light comes on is there any danger to employees.

senses.definition: a situation that is not certain

examples.en: If he wins—and it's a big if—he'll be the first Scot to win for fifty years.
There are still a lot of ifs and buts before everything's settled.

senses.definition: a poem published in 1910 by Rudyard Kipling. It consists of a single long sentence beginning with the word ‘if’, giving advice to a boy on how to become a man. It is in the Victorian tradition and now seems rather old-fashioned, but the poem remains extremely popular and is often voted the favourite poem of British readers.
a lack of knowledge or information about something

examples.en: They fought a long battle against prejudice and ignorance.
I hate to admit my ignorance, but how does it work?
He showed a remarkable ignorance of the facts.
widespread ignorance about the disease
They were kept in ignorance of their government's activities.
Children often behave badly out of ignorance.
Many lives are lost through ignorance.

senses.definition: the state of not knowing about something and so being unable to worry about it

examples.en: We preferred to remain in blissful ignorance of what was going on.

senses.definition: if you do not know about something, you cannot worry about it

examples.en: Some doctors believe ignorance is bliss and don't give their patients all the facts.

senses.definition: to pay no attention to something

examples.en: He ignored the 30 mph speed limit sign and accelerated down the road.
I made a suggestion but they chose to ignore it.
We cannot afford to ignore their advice.
to ignore a warning/a problem/an issue
She deliberately ignored my question and changed the subject.
We can't ignore the fact that there is a huge problem here.
His work was largely ignored and forgotten for 30 years.
Much of social science research simply ignores these sectors.
The government has completely ignored the wishes of the public.

senses.definition: to pretend that you have not seen somebody or that somebody is not there

examples.en: She ignored him and carried on with her work.
If he tries to start an argument, just ignore him.

variants.html: (North American English usually sick)

senses.definition: suffering from an illness or disease; not feeling well

examples.en: Her father is seriously ill in St Luke's hospital.
critically/gravely/severely ill
Uncle Harry is terminally ill with cancer (= he will die from his illness).
chronically ill patients (= who are ill for a long time )
She was taken ill suddenly.
We both started to feel ill shortly after the meal.
veterans who became ill after fighting in the Gulf War
Shortly after drinking the water I was violently ill.
He fell ill and died soon after.
I can't eat bananas as they make me ill.
She'd been ill with cancer for months.

senses.definition: bad or harmful

examples.en: She suffered no ill effects from the experience.
a house of ill repute (= with a bad reputation, especially because behaviour that is not considered moral happens there)

senses.definition: that brings, or is thought to bring, bad luck

examples.en: a bird of ill omen

variants.text: (also bad/ill feelings especially in North American English)
variants.html: (also bad/ill feelings especially in North American English)

senses.definition: anger between people, especially after an argument

examples.en: There was a lot of bad feeling between the two groups of students.
I don't want any bad feelings between us.

senses.definition: feeling uncomfortable and embarrassed

examples.en: I felt ill at ease in such formal clothes.

variants.text: (also ill/bad feelings especially in North American English)
variants.html: (also ill/bad feelings especially in North American English)

senses.definition: anger between people, especially after an argument

examples.en: There was a lot of ill feeling between the two groups of students.
I don't want any ill feelings between us.

idioms.word: it’s an ill wind (that blows nobody any good)

senses.definition: no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody
badly or in an unpleasant way

examples.en: The animals had been grossly ill-treated.

senses.definition: badly; not in an acceptable way

examples.en: They live in an area ill served by public transport.

senses.definition: only with difficulty

examples.en: We're wasting valuable time, time we can ill afford.
I can ill afford the time or the money for a holiday.

senses.definition: to be a good/bad sign for somebody/something

examples.en: These figures do not bode well for the company's future.
The look on her face boded ill for anyone who crossed her path that day.

senses.definition: to say or think bad things about somebody

examples.en: Don't speak ill of the dead.

senses.definition: people who are ill

examples.en: Even the seriously ill cannot get tests done immediately.

senses.definition: a problem or harmful thing; an illness

examples.en: social/economic ills
the ills of the modern world

senses.definition: harm; bad luck

examples.en: I may not like him, but I wish him no ill.

senses.definition: not allowed by the law

examples.en: illegal drugs/firearms/substances
She promised to crack down on illegal immigration.
illegal immigrants/aliens
His illegal activities landed him in jail several times.
illegal mining/fishing/gambling
These proposals are unethical and possibly illegal.

examples.cf: it is illegal to do something
examples.en: It's illegal to drive through a red light.

examples.cf: it is illegal for somebody to do something
examples.en: It is illegal for anyone under 18 to possess fireworks in a public place.

labels: (especially North American English, disapproving, often offensive)

senses.definition: a person who lives or works in a country illegally
the state of being physically or mentally ill

examples.en: The virus can cause illness in humans.
mental/respiratory/chronic illness
I missed a lot of school through illness last year.

senses.definition: a type or period of illness

examples.en: serious/severe/chronic illnesses
a terminal illness
childhood illnesses
He died after a long illness.
She suffers from a debilitating illness.

senses.definition: a false idea or belief, especially about somebody or about a situation

examples.en: She's under the illusion that (= believes wrongly that) she'll get the job.
The new president has no illusions about the difficulties facing her country (= she knows that the country has serious problems).
I have no illusions about her feelings for me (= I know the truth is that she does not love me).
He could no longer distinguish between illusion and reality.
I don’t want to have my illusions shattered!

senses.definition: something that seems to exist but in fact does not, or seems to be something that it is not

examples.en: Mirrors in a room often give an illusion of space.
The idea of absolute personal freedom is an illusion.

senses.definition: to use pictures, photographs, diagrams, etc. in a book, etc.

examples.en: She illustrated her own books.
His lecture was illustrated with photos taken during the expedition.

senses.definition: to make the meaning of something clearer by using examples, pictures, etc.

examples.en: To illustrate my point, let me tell you a little story.
Last year's sales figures are illustrated in Figure 2.
He is showing these silent films to help illustrate his story of survival.
Each topic is illustrated with concrete examples of economic practice.
Here's an example to illustrate what I mean.

senses.definition: to show that something is true or that a situation exists

examples.en: The incident illustrates the need for better security measures.
This story illustrates how little has changed.
These data illustrate that many parents are not aware of the risks.

senses.definition: a drawing or picture in a book, magazine, for decoration or to explain something

examples.en: 50 full-colour illustrations
detailed illustrations of animals, birds and plants
a volume of Chaucer with illustrations by Edward Burne-Jones
He produced illustrations for children's books.

senses.definition: the process of illustrating something

examples.en: the art of book illustration

senses.definition: a story, an event or an example that clearly shows the truth about something

examples.en: The statistics are a clear illustration of the point I am trying to make.
I use this case as an illustration.
Let me, by way of illustration, quote from one of her poems.

senses.definition: a picture, photograph or statue that represents somebody/something

examples.en: Most simple leaflets will include text and images.
We already have more than 22  000 digital images on file.
The visual image is steadily replacing the written word.
Images of deer and hunters decorate the cave walls.
Consider the images of war that fill the pages of our newspapers.
a wooden image of the Hindu god Ganesh
An exhibition of images of St Nicholas is on display in the cathedral.
In the Bible it states that humans were created in the image of God.

senses.definition: a picture of somebody/something seen in a mirror, through a camera, or on a television, computer, phone, etc.

examples.en: He stared at his own image reflected in the water.
Slowly, an image began to appear on the screen.
Click on the image for a larger version.
Police will study the images from CCTV cameras.
The camera captured an image of the suspect and his car.
The satellite provides high-resolution images of the Earth's surface.
The image quality is too low.

senses.definition: the impression that a person, an organization, a product, etc. gives to the public

examples.en: His public image is very different from the real person.
The advertisements are intended to improve the company's image.
Image is very important in the music world.
It was years before the country was able to project an image of stability again.
The campaign aims to create a new image for the city.
stereotyped images of women in children’s books
to have a positive/negative image
The company changed its name on the advice of an image consultant.

senses.definition: a mental picture that you have of what somebody/something is like or looks like

examples.en: images of the past
I had a mental image of what she would look like.
Dieting always seems to conjure up images of endless cottage cheese salads.

senses.definition: a word or phrase used with a different meaning from its normal one, in order to describe something in a way that produces a strong picture in the mind

examples.en: Her writings are full of poetic images of the countryside.

senses.definition: to look very like somebody/something else

examples.en: He's the image of his father.

senses.definition: language that produces pictures in the minds of people reading or listening

examples.en: poetic imagery

senses.definition: pictures, photographs, etc.

examples.en: satellite imagery (= for example, photographs of the earth taken from space)

senses.definition: existing only in your mind or imagination

examples.en: The equator is an imaginary line around the middle of the earth.
I had an imaginary friend when I was a child.
As children they invented the imaginary world of Gondal.
We must listen to their problems, real or imaginary.

senses.definition: the ability to create pictures in your mind; the part of your mind that does this

examples.en: a vivid/fertile imagination
He has no imagination.
It doesn't take much imagination to guess what she meant.
I won't tell you his reaction—I'll leave that to your imagination.
Don't let your imagination run away with you (= don't use too much imagination).
The new policies appear to have captured the imagination of the public (= they find them interesting and exciting)
His stories really stretch children’s imaginations.
Nobody hates you—it's all in your imagination.
This is an image which persists in the popular imagination.
Use your imagination! (= used to tell somebody that they will have to guess the answer to the question they have asked you, usually because it is obvious or embarrassing)

senses.definition: something that you have imagined rather than something that exists

examples.en: She was no longer able to distinguish between imagination and reality.
Is it my imagination or have you lost a lot of weight?

senses.definition: the ability to have new and exciting ideas

examples.en: His writing lacks imagination.
With a little imagination, you could turn this place into a palace.
We are looking for someone with ingenuity and imagination.

senses.definition: to allow more of somebody’s body to be seen than usual

examples.en: Her tight-fitting dress left nothing to the imagination.

idioms.word: not by any stretch of the imagination | by no stretch of the imagination

senses.definition: used to say strongly that something is not true, even if you try to imagine or believe it

examples.en: She could not, by any stretch of the imagination, be called beautiful.
By no stretch of the imagination could the trip be described as relaxing.

senses.definition: to form a picture in your mind of what something might be like

examples.en: The house was just as she had imagined it.
Imagine my surprise when I opened the door to find him standing there.
I can't imagine life without the children now.
It's hard to imagine a more cynical political strategy.
Close your eyes and imagine (that) you are in a forest.
Can you imagine what it must be like to lose your job after 20 years?
Imagine earning that much money!
She imagined walking into the office and handing in her resignation.
I can just imagine him saying that!
I had imagined her to be older than that.
He loved to imagine himself as the hero.
I find it difficult to imagine her a grandmother.
I can imagine him really angry.
‘He was furious.’ ‘I can imagine.’

senses.definition: to believe something that is not true

examples.en: He’s always imagining (that) we’re talking about him behind his back.
There's nobody there. You're imagining things.

senses.definition: to think that something is probably true

examples.en: ‘Can we still buy tickets for the concert?’ ‘I imagine so.’
I don’t imagine (that) they’ll refuse.

senses.definition: happening or done without delay

examples.en: an immediate reaction/response
to take immediate action
RAM stores information for immediate access.
This decision will have an immediate impact on students.
The company announced the immediate availability of an updated version of the software.

senses.definition: existing now and needing attention quickly

examples.en: Our immediate concern is to help the families of those who died.
The hospital says she's out of immediate danger.
weapons of mass destruction that were an immediate threat to international security
The report focuses on some of the more immediate problems facing us.
He said there was no immediate need to appeal for international assistance.

senses.definition: next to or very close to a particular place or time

examples.en: in the immediate vicinity
in the immediate aftermath of the war
The prospects for the immediate future are good.
The director is standing on her immediate right.
my immediate predecessor in the job (= the person who had the job just before me)

senses.definition: nearest in relationship or rank

examples.en: The funeral was attended by her immediate family (= her parents, children, brothers and sisters) only.
He is my immediate superior (= the person directly above me) in the company.

senses.definition: having a direct effect

examples.en: The immediate cause of death is unknown.

senses.definition: starting now

examples.en: She has resigned with immediate effect.

senses.definition: without delay

examples.en: She answered almost immediately.
They immediately began arguing.
The point of my question may not be immediately apparent.
It is immediately clear that he is out of his depth.
Details were not immediately available.

senses.definition: next to or very close to a particular place or time

examples.en: Turn right immediately after the church.
the land immediately adjacent to the river
the years immediately before the war
in the two weeks immediately prior to the exam
Who is immediately above a colonel in rank?
the period immediately following her birth
The film takes place in the days immediately preceding the invasion.

senses.definition: closely and directly

senses.definition: as soon as

examples.en: Immediately she'd gone, I remembered her name.

senses.definition: extremely large or great

examples.en: There is still an immense amount of work to be done.
The benefits are immense.
a project of immense importance
To my immense relief, he didn’t notice my mistake.

senses.definition: a person who has come to live permanently in a different country from the one they were born in

examples.en: immigrants from other European countries
immigrants to the United States
Immigrants and their descendants have played a vital role in building this nation.
The president vowed to continue deporting illegal immigrants.
The program protects undocumented immigrants who came to the US as children.
immigrant workers/communities/groups

senses.definition: the process of coming to live permanently in a different country from the one you were born in; the number of people who do this

examples.en: legal/illegal immigration

laws restricting immigration into the US
There was an increase in immigration from Eastern Europe.
immigration policy/reform

senses.definition: the place at a port, an airport, etc. where the passports and other documents of people coming into a country are checked

examples.en: We landed at Heathrow and went through customs and immigration.
immigration officers
The men were interviewed by immigration officials.

senses.definition: likely to happen very soon

examples.en: the imminent threat of invasion
The system is in imminent danger of collapse.
An announcement about his resignation is imminent.
An attack seems imminent.

senses.definition: that cannot catch or be affected by a particular disease or illness

examples.en: Adults are often immune to German measles.

senses.definition: not affected by something, especially something that you might expect to be harmful

examples.en: You'll eventually become immune to criticism.
Few people are immune to her charms.
Our business is far from immune to economic conditions.

senses.definition: protected from something and therefore able to avoid it

examples.en: No one should be immune from prosecution.
Not even the monarch was immune from criticism by the press.

senses.definition: the powerful effect that something has on somebody/something

examples.en: a positive/a negative/an adverse impact
a significant/major/huge impact
to have/make an impact
to reduce/minimize the impact of something
the environmental impact of tourism
the economic impact of leaving the European Union
Her speech made a profound impact on everyone.
He has had a lasting impact on the lives of many of his students.
The project's impact on the environment should be minimal.
The report assesses the impact of the disease on mortality and population growth.

an environmental impact assessment
a victim impact statement

senses.definition: the act of one object hitting another; the force with which this happens

examples.en: craters made by meteorite impacts

A well-designed sports shoe should absorb the impact on the 28 bones in each foot.
The bomb explodes on impact (= when it hits something).
The car is fitted with side impact bars (= to protect it from a blow from the side).

senses.definition: to have an effect on somebody/something

examples.en: Her father's death impacted greatly on her childhood years.
These restrictions will impact on all farmers in Ireland.
environmental factors that may negatively impact children's development
The company's performance was impacted by the high value of the pound.

senses.definition: to hit something with great force
annoyed by somebody/something, especially because you have to wait for a long time

examples.en: I'd been waiting for twenty minutes and I was getting impatient.
The children were growing impatient.
Try not to be too impatient with her.
Sarah was becoming increasingly impatient at their lack of interest.
An impatient driver behind me sounded his horn.
She waved them away with an impatient gesture.

senses.definition: wanting to do something soon; wanting something to happen soon

examples.en: She was clearly impatient to leave.
impatient for change

senses.definition: unable or unwilling to accept something unpleasant

examples.en: impatient of criticism

senses.definition: to make something that has been officially decided start to happen or be used

examples.en: to implement changes/decisions/policies/reforms
A new work programme for young people will be implemented.

senses.definition: a tool or an instrument, often one that is quite simple and that is used outdoors

examples.en: agricultural implements
Make sure that all sharp implements, such as scythes, have covers.

senses.definition: the act of making something that has been officially decided start to happen or be used

examples.en: the implementation of the new system

senses.definition: a possible effect or result of an action or a decision

examples.en: They failed to consider the wider implications of their actions.
The development of the site will have implications for the surrounding countryside.

senses.definition: something that is suggested or indirectly stated (= something that is implied)

examples.en: I resent the implication that I don't care about my father.
He criticized the Director and, by implication, the whole of the organization.

senses.definition: the fact of being involved, or of involving somebody, in something, especially a crime

examples.en: He resigned after his implication in a sex scandal.

senses.definition: to suggest that something is true or that you feel or think something, without saying so directly

examples.en: Are you implying (that) I am wrong?
His silence seemed to imply agreement.
High-yield bonds, as the name implies, offer a high rate of interest.
It was implied that we were at fault.

senses.definition: to make it seem likely that something is true or exists

examples.en: The survey implies (that) more people are moving house than was thought.
It was implied in the survey that…
Popularity does not necessarily imply merit.
The fact that she was here implies a degree of interest.

senses.definition: to make something necessary in order to be successful

examples.en: The project implies an enormous investment in training.
Sustainable development implies a long-term perspective.

senses.definition: a product or service that is brought into one country from another

examples.en: food imports from abroad
cheap imports into the United States

senses.definition: the act of bringing a product or service into one country from another

examples.en: The report calls for a ban on the import of hazardous waste.
imports of oil
import duties/tariffs
import controls/restrictions/quotas
an import licence
A restricted import quota was set for meat products.
the UK's net imports of food
Most of their oil revenues are used to finance imports of consumer and capital goods.

senses.definition: importance

examples.en: matters of great import

senses.definition: the meaning of something, especially when it is not immediately clear

examples.en: It is difficult to understand the full import of this statement.

senses.definition: to bring a product or service into one country from another

examples.en: The country has to import most of its raw materials.
the cost of importing petroleum products into the country
goods imported from Japan into the US

senses.definition: to bring an idea into one country or region from another

examples.en: customs imported from the West

senses.definition: to get data from another program, changing its form so that the program you are using can read it
the quality of being important

examples.en: She stressed the importance of careful preparation.
to emphasize/highlight the importance of something
He understands the importance of getting the details right.
They attach great importance to the project.
the relative importance of the two ideas
It's a matter of the utmost importance to me.
to be of paramount/vital importance
State your reasons in order of importance.
He was very aware of his own importance (= of his status).

senses.definition: having a great effect on people or things; of great value

examples.en: an important issue/question/point/factor
We have an important decision to make.
Money played an important role in his life.
Listening is an important part of the job.
one of the most important collections of American art
The important thing is to keep trying.
The centre is extremely important to many local people.
Banks are vitally important to the economy.
Many chemicals are important for our health.

examples.cf: it is important to do something
examples.en: It is important to follow the manufacturer's instructions.
It is important to note that total government funding has increased.
It's important to remember that our figures are averages only.
It is important that he attend every day.
It is important that he should attend every day.

examples.cf: it is important to somebody that…
examples.en: It's very important to me that you be there.
It's very important to me that you should be there.

examples.cf: it is important for somebody/something to do something
examples.en: It is important for him to attend every day.

senses.definition: having great influence or authority

examples.en: an important member of the team
He likes to feel important.

senses.definition: to introduce a new law, rule, tax, etc.; to order that a rule, punishment, etc. be used

examples.en: The UN Security Council imposed sanctions in 1992.
to impose a penalty/fine/sentence/ban
A new tax was imposed on fuel.

senses.definition: to force somebody/something to have to deal with something that is difficult or unpleasant

examples.en: He described the limitations imposed by his disease.

to impose restrictions/constraints/obligations on somebody/something
The time limits are imposed on us by factors outside our control.

senses.definition: to make somebody accept the same opinions, wishes, etc. as your own

examples.en: She didn't want to impose her values on her family.

senses.definition: to expect somebody to do something for you or to spend time with you, when it may not be convenient for them

senses.definition: to make somebody/something accept or be aware of your presence or ideas

senses.definition: that cannot exist or be done; not possible

examples.en: almost/virtually/nearly impossible

an impossible dream/goal

It's impossible to prove.
Cheap rental accommodation was impossible to find.

examples.cf: it is impossible to do something
examples.en: It's impossible to say which is the best.
It is impossible to tell whether it will actually work.
I find it impossible to lie to her.

examples.cf: it is impossible for somebody to do something
examples.en: It's impossible for me to be there before eight.

senses.definition: very difficult to deal with

examples.en: I've been placed in an impossible position.
Honestly, you're impossible at times!

senses.definition: a thing that is or seems impossible

examples.en: to attempt the impossible

senses.definition: a difficult or impossible task

examples.en: Many regard this task as mission impossible.

senses.definition: if a person or thing impresses you, you admire them or it

The Grand Canyon never fails to impress.

senses.definition: to make somebody understand how important, serious, etc. something is by emphasizing it

examples.en: He impressed on us the need for immediate action.

senses.definition: to have a great effect on something, especially somebody’s mind, imagination, etc.

examples.en: Her words impressed themselves on my memory.

examples.en: I must admit I am impressed.

He was impressed at the way the team had played.

examples.cf: impressed to see, hear, find, etc.
examples.en: We were impressed to see how well they'd done already.
I was impressed that she remembered my name.

senses.definition: an idea, a feeling or an opinion that you get about somebody/something, or that somebody/something gives you

examples.en: My first impression of him was favourable.

senses.definition: the effect that an experience or a person has on somebody/something

examples.en: You'll have to play better than that if you really want to make an impression (= to make people admire you).

senses.definition: a drawing showing what a person looks like or what a place or a building will look like in the future

examples.en: This is an artist's impression of the new stadium.

senses.definition: a clever or funny copy of the way a person acts or speaks

examples.en: He did an impression of the prime minister.

senses.definition: an appearance that may be false

examples.en: Clever lighting creates an impression of space in a room.

senses.definition: a mark that is left when an object is pressed hard into a surface

examples.en: The dentist made an impression of his teeth.

senses.definition: all the copies of a book that are printed at one time, with few or no changes to the contents since the last time the book was printed
believing, usually wrongly, that something is true or is happening

examples.en: I was under the impression that the work had already been completed.

senses.definition: making you admire them, because they are very large, good, skilful, etc.

examples.en: an impressive performance
an impressive array/list/collection
an impressive display of skill

an impressive building with a huge tower
one of the most impressive novels of recent years

senses.definition: to put somebody in a prison or another place from which they cannot escape

examples.en: They were imprisoned for a crime they didn't commit.

senses.definition: the act of putting somebody in a prison or another place from which they cannot escape; the state of being there

examples.en: to be sentenced to life imprisonment for murder

senses.definition: to become better than before; to make something/somebody better than before

senses.definition: showing signs of improvement

a slight/steady improvement

The work should lead to an improvement in water quality.

senses.definition: the fact of not being able to do something

senses.definition: not enough; not good enough

senses.definition: not able, or not confident enough, to deal with a situation

senses.definition: not suitable or appropriate in a particular situation

examples.en: inappropriate behaviour/language

examples.cf: it is inappropriate (for somebody/something) (to do something)

senses.definition: something that encourages you to do something

senses.definition: a payment or concession (= a reduction in the amount of money that has to be paid) that encourages somebody to do something

examples.en: tax incentives to encourage savings

senses.definition: a unit for measuring length or height, equal to 2.54 centimetres. There are 12 inches in a foot.

a fat envelope about half an inch thick

senses.definition: a small amount or distance

senses.definition: completely

idioms.word: give somebody an inch (and they’ll take a mile/yard)

senses.definition: used to say that if you allow some people a small amount of freedom or power they will see you as weak and try to take a lot more
very slowly and with great care or difficulty

examples.en: She crawled forward inch by inch.

senses.definition: to refuse to change your position, decision, etc. even a little

examples.en: We tried to negotiate a lower price but they wouldn't budge an inch.

senses.definition: to not trust somebody at all

examples.en: He says he just wants to help you but I wouldn’t trust him an inch if I were you.

senses.definition: to move or make something move slowly and carefully in a particular direction

examples.en: She moved forward, inching towards the rope.

senses.definition: the extent to which something happens or has an effect

examples.en: an area with a high incidence of crime

senses.definition: the way in which light meets a surface

examples.en: the angle of incidence

senses.definition: something that happens, especially something unusual or unpleasant

senses.definition: a serious or violent event, such as a crime, an accident or an attack

examples.en: a violent/serious incident

senses.definition: a disagreement between two countries, often involving military forces

examples.en: a border/diplomatic incident

senses.definition: touching or hitting a surface

examples.en: The technology relies on a beam of incident light passing through a prism.

senses.definition: wanting to do something

senses.definition: tending to do something; likely to do something

senses.cf: inclined to agree, believe, think, etc.

examples.en: I'm inclined to agree with you.

senses.definition: having a natural ability for something; preferring to do something

senses.definition: sloping; at an angle

variants.html: (abbreviation incl., British English also inc.)

senses.definition: having something as part of a group or set

examples.en: I've got three days' holiday including New Year's Day.

senses.definition: the fact of including somebody/something; the fact of being included

examples.en: His inclusion in the team is in doubt.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is included

examples.en: There were some surprising inclusions in the list.

senses.definition: the fact or policy of providing equal opportunities and resources for people who might otherwise not get them, for example people who are disabled or belong to minority groups

examples.en: The company is actively promoting diversity and inclusion.

senses.definition: the money that a person, a region, a country, etc. earns from work, from investing money, from business, etc.

examples.en: Average household income fell slightly.
a weekly disposable income (= the money that you have left to spend after tax, etc.) of £400

Net income for the year was $43m.
a rise in national income
Trying to earn an income as an artist can be hard.
Some low-paid workers supplement their income with second jobs.
Tourism generates income for the local economy.
These tax changes should help people on low incomes.
New figures show a drop in income for the newly retired.
They lived on the rental income from the property.

Tourism is a major source of income for the area.
Both higher- and lower-income groups will be paying more tax from next year.

senses.definition: to include something so that it forms a part of something

examples.en: The new car design incorporates all the latest safety features.
We have incorporated all the latest safety features into the design.
Many of your suggestions have been incorporated in the plan.

senses.definition: to create a legally recognized company

examples.en: The company was incorporated in 2008.

senses.definition: not accurate or true

examples.en: incorrect information/spelling
His version of what happened is incorrect.

senses.definition: speaking or behaving in a way that does not follow the accepted standards or rules
to become greater in amount, number, value, etc.; to make something greater in amount, number, value, etc.

examples.en: Costs have increased significantly.
to increase dramatically/substantially
The price of oil increased.
Oil increased in price.
The rate of inflation increased by 2 per cent.
The population has increased from 1.2 million to 1.8 million.
The effectiveness of the vaccine increases with time (= the more time passes, the more effective it is).
Sun exposure may increase the risk of skin cancer.
Our aim is to increase the number of women in the sport.

examples.cf: increase something from A to B

increasing levels of carbon dioxide in the earth’s atmosphere

senses.definition: a rise in the amount, number or value of something

examples.en: price/tax/wage increases

Last year the business saw a 3% increase in turnover.
a substantial increase in the number of products on the market

an increase of 2p in the pound on income tax

This is an increase of 12% on the previous year.
This represents a 14% increase over last year.

The rate of increase is accelerating.

senses.definition: more and more all the time

examples.en: Tourism is playing an increasingly important role in the region's economy
increasingly difficult/popular
It is becoming increasingly clear that this problem will not be easily solved.
It is looking increasingly likely that no agreement will be reached.
Doctors are growing increasingly concerned about his condition.

senses.definition: impossible or very difficult to believe

examples.en: an incredible story

examples.cf: it is incredible to somebody that…

examples.cf: it is incredible to do something

senses.definition: extremely good

examples.en: The hotel was incredible.

The trip to Costa Rica was an incredible experience.

examples.cf: it is incredible to do something

senses.definition: extremely large

examples.en: an incredible amount of work

senses.definition: extremely

examples.en: It was all incredibly difficult.
organizations doing incredibly important work
incredibly stupid/boring
incredibly powerful/strong
incredibly lucky/talented/beautiful

senses.definition: in a way that is very difficult to believe

examples.en: Incredibly, she had no idea what was going on.

senses.definition: if you incur something unpleasant, you are in a situation in which you have to deal with it

senses.definition: if you incur costs, you have to pay them

examples.en: You risk incurring bank charges if you exceed your overdraft limit.

senses.definition: used after very and an adjective or adverb to emphasize a statement, description, etc.

examples.en: Thank you very much indeed!
I was very sad indeed to hear of your father's death.
The last three months have been very good indeed for the company.

senses.definition: used to emphasize a positive statement or answer

examples.en: ‘Was he very angry?’ ‘Indeed he was.’
‘Do you agree?’ ‘Indeed I do/Yes, indeed.’
‘You said you'd help?’ ‘I did indeed—yes.’
It is indeed a remarkable achievement.

senses.definition: used to add information to a statement

examples.en: I don't mind at all. Indeed, I would be delighted to help.
Today's youth live in a more affluent society than their grandparents, indeed even their parents.

senses.definition: used to show that you are surprised at something or that you find something silly

examples.en: A ghost indeed! I've never heard anything so silly.

senses.definition: used when you are repeating a question that somebody has just asked and showing that you do not know the answer

examples.en: ‘Why did he do it?’ ‘Why indeed?’

idioms.word: a friend in need (is a friend indeed)

senses.definition: a friend who gives you help when you need it (is a true friend)
freedom from political control by other countries

examples.en: Argentina gained independence from Spain in 1816.

senses.definition: the time when a country gains freedom from political control by another country

examples.en: independence celebrations
the first elections since independence

senses.definition: the freedom to organize your own life, make your own decisions, etc. without needing help from other people

examples.en: He values his independence.
Financial independence was imprortant to her.

senses.definition: a US city in the state of Missouri. President Harry S Truman lived there, and his official library and museum can be visited. The international office of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints is also there. In the 1830s and 1840s, people began their journeys west on the Santa Fe Trail and the Oregon Trail from Independence.
having its own government

examples.en: an independent state/nation/country
the newly independent republics of Central Asia in the 1990s
Mozambique became independent in 1975.
In 1961 the country was declared independent.
The country became fully independent from France in 1960.
Adams urged Congress to declare the American colonies independent of Britain.

senses.definition: confident and free to do things without needing help from other people

examples.en: Going away to college has made me much more independent.
She's a very independent-minded young woman.
Pat has always been fiercely independent.
Students should aim to become more independent of their teachers.

senses.definition: having or earning enough money so that you do not have to rely on somebody else for help

examples.en: It was important to me to be financially independent of my parents.
a man of independent means (= with an income that he does not earn by working)

senses.definition: done or given by somebody who is not involved in a situation and so is able to judge it fairly

examples.en: an independent inquiry/review/investigation
an independent commission/body/panel
an independent adviser/consultant/expert
She went to a lawyer for some independent advice.
The auditing of a company's accounts is done by independent accountants.

senses.definition: not connected with or influenced by something; not connected with each other

examples.en: The police force should be independent of direct government control.
Two independent research bodies reached the same conclusions.
The results were obtained from four independent experiments.

senses.definition: supported by private money rather than government money

examples.en: independent television
the independent sector

senses.definition: not employed or controlled by a company; not created by a big company

examples.en: She was hired to do the work as an independent contractor.
Farmers operate as independent producers in the sense of working for themselves and running their own business.
a low-budget independent film

senses.definition: not representing or belonging to a particular political party

examples.en: an independent candidate

senses.definition: a member of parliament, candidate, etc. who does not belong to a particular political party

examples.en: She's standing as an independent at the next election.

senses.definition: a person who runs their own small business and is not employed or controlled by a company

examples.en: It's getting tougher and tougher for independents in the music business.

senses.definition: a list of names or topics that are referred to in a book, etc., usually arranged at the end of a book in alphabetical order or listed in a separate file or book

examples.en: Look it up in the index.
Author and subject indexes are available on a library database.

variants.text: (also card index (British English), North American English card catalog)
variants.html: (also card index (British English), North American English card catalog)

senses.definition: a box of cards with information on them, arranged in alphabetical order
a system that shows the level of prices and wages, etc. so that they can be compared with those of a previous date

examples.en: the cost-of-living index
The Dow Jones index fell 15 points this morning.
stock market indices
house price indexes

senses.definition: a number giving a measurement of something compared with a particular standard

examples.en: White bread has a high glycaemic index.
pain management index scores

senses.definition: a sign or measure that something else can be judged by

examples.en: The number of new houses being built is a good index of a country's prosperity.

senses.definition: a list of the records in a computer file with information about where each is located

examples.en: Search the index to find the address of the data file.
The index of a search engine is like a library.

variants.html: (usually indices [plural])

senses.definition: the small number written above a larger number to show how many times that number must be multiplied by itself. In the equation 42 = 16, the number 2 is an index.
to make an index of documents, the contents of a book, etc.; to add something to a list of this type

examples.en: All publications are indexed by subject and title.
New material is scanned, indexed and stored electronically.

senses.definition: to link wages, etc. to the level of prices of food, clothing, etc. so that they both increase at the same rate

examples.en: The basic state pension is indexed to inflation.

senses.definition: to show that something is true or exists

examples.en: Initial tests indicate the presence of oxygen.
The survey data indicate a general satisfaction with the process.
Although the president promised to foster unity, his actions have indicated otherwise.
Research indicates that eating habits are changing fast.
These findings clearly indicate that the scheme has improved pedestrian safety.
The study/evidence/report indicates that…
Kingston-upon-Thames, as the name indicates, is situated on the banks of the Thames.
Our results indicate how misleading it could be to rely on this method.

senses.definition: to be a sign of something; to show that something is possible or likely

examples.en: A red sky at night often indicates fine weather the next day.
Early results indicate that the government will be returned to power.
These figures indicate to me that the company is in serious trouble.

senses.definition: to mention something, especially in an indirect way

examples.en: In his letter he indicated to us (that) he was willing to cooperate.
He indicated his willingness to cooperate.
Has she indicated yet whether she would like to be involved?

senses.definition: to make somebody notice somebody/something, especially by pointing or moving your head

examples.en: ‘What are they doing here?’ he asked, indicating her bags in the hallway.
She took out a map and indicated the quickest route to us.
He indicated where the furniture was to go.
She indicated that I was to sit down.

senses.definition: to represent information without using words

examples.en: Arrows indicate the direction of flow.
The results are indicated in Table 2.

senses.definition: to give information in writing

examples.en: You are allowed 20  kg of baggage unless indicated otherwise on your ticket.
As indicated above, this chapter deals with the practical implications of the research.
Please indicate clearly which colour you require.

senses.definition: to show a particular measurement

examples.en: When the temperature gauge indicates 30°C or more, turn off the engine.

senses.definition: to show that your vehicle is going to change direction, by using lights or your arm

examples.en: Always indicate before moving into another lane.
He indicated left and then turned right.
She indicated that she was turning right.

senses.definition: to be necessary or recommended

examples.en: A course of chemotherapy was indicated.

senses.definition: a remark or sign that shows that something is happening or what somebody is thinking or feeling

examples.en: They gave no indication of how the work should be done.
He shows every indication (= clear signs) of wanting to accept the post.
There are clear indications that the economy is improving.
All the indications are that the deal will go ahead as planned.

senses.definition: a symptom that suggests that particular medical treatment is necessary

examples.en: There was no clinical indication for such a test.

senses.definition: a sign that shows you what something is like or how a situation is changing

examples.en: The economic indicators are better than expected.
These atmospheric waves are a reliable indicator of weather changes.

senses.definition: a device on a machine that shows speed, pressure, etc.

examples.en: a depth indicator

variants.html: (North American English turn signal)

senses.definition: a light on a vehicle that flashes to show that the vehicle is going to turn left or right

examples.en: Her right-hand indicator was flashing.
He flicked on his indicator light and passed the lorry.

senses.definition: a sign that a system, society, etc. is very bad or very wrong

examples.en: The poverty in our cities is a damning indictment of modern society.
This research is a terrible indictment on the medical profession.

senses.definition: an official statement accusing somebody of a crime

examples.en: She was convicted on an indictment for conspiracy.
The federal district court dismissed the indictment.
The government announced a federal indictment against him.
They issued an indictment against them.
Two men were named in the indictment.
War crimes indictments were handed down by a UN-backed court.
an indictment charging theft
There is sufficient evidence against him to support an indictment for murder.

senses.definition: the act of officially accusing somebody of a crime

examples.en: This led to his indictment on allegations of conspiracy.

senses.definition: coming from a particular place and having lived there for a long time before other people came there; relating to, belonging to or developed by these people

examples.en: the indigenous peoples/languages of an area
Indigenous Australians/Canadians
indigenous land/territory
She campaigns for indigenous rights.

senses.definition: having originally developed in a particular place, rather than having been brought there from somewhere else

examples.en: The kangaroo is indigenous to Australia.

senses.definition: happening not as the main aim, cause or result of a particular action, but in addition to it

examples.en: the indirect effects of the war

The building collapsed as an indirect result of the heavy rain.
There would be some benefit, however indirect, to the state.

senses.definition: not done directly; done through somebody/something else

examples.en: territories under the indirect control of the British

senses.definition: avoiding saying something in a clear and obvious way

examples.en: The comment was an indirect attack on the prime minister.
The president made an indirect reference to the subject in his speech.

senses.definition: not going in a straight line

examples.en: an indirect route
The plant prefers indirect sunlight.

senses.definition: a person considered separately rather than as part of a group

examples.en: The competition is open to both teams and individuals.

Differences between individuals affect their susceptibility to disease.

senses.definition: a single member of a class of things

examples.en: They live in a group or as individuals, depending on the species.

senses.definition: a person who is original and very different from others

examples.en: She's grown into quite an individual.
She saw the artist as a unique individual, possessing a heightened awareness of reality.

senses.definition: a person of a particular type, especially a strange one

examples.en: an odd-looking individual
So this individual came up and demanded money.
This scruffy-looking individual wandered into the office.

senses.definition: considered separately rather than as part of a group

examples.en: We interviewed each individual member of the community.
The minister refused to comment on individual cases.
Farmers each have their own individual concerns about the changes.
The individual members of the team must all be motivated to contribute.

senses.definition: connected with one person; designed for one person

examples.en: respect for individual freedom
The bill addresses an issue of individual liberty.
A democracy must protect individual rights.
an individual pizza

senses.definition: typical of one particular person or thing in a way that is different from others

examples.en: a highly individual style of dress

senses.definition: located, done or used inside a building

examples.en: an indoor swimming pool
indoor games

senses.definition: relating to sports played indoors

examples.en: the world indoor 200 metres champion

senses.definition: inside or into a building

examples.en: I prefer to stay indoors in this really hot weather.
Let's go indoors.
I was indoors watching TV when I heard shouting in the street.
Many herbs can be grown indoors.
She added that in Hong Kong most cats were kept indoors.

senses.definition: to persuade or influence somebody to do something

examples.en: Nothing would induce me to take the job.

senses.definition: to cause something

examples.en: drugs that induce sleep
a drug-induced coma
Hearing loss is often induced by exposure to loud noise.

senses.definition: to make a woman start giving birth to her baby by giving her special drugs; to make a baby start being born by giving the mother special drugs

examples.en: an induced labour
We'll have to induce her.
I was admitted and the baby was induced at 35 weeks.

senses.definition: to allow yourself to have or do something that you like, especially something that is considered bad for you

examples.en: They went into town to indulge in some serious shopping.

senses.definition: to be too generous in allowing somebody to have or do whatever they like

examples.en: She did not believe in indulging the children with presents.

senses.definition: to take part in an activity, especially one that is illegal
connected with industry

examples.en: an industrial dispute
industrial unrest
an industrial accident

policy with regard to future industrial development
India has a large industrial sector.
a huge industrial complex
the country's industrial base

senses.definition: used by industries

examples.en: industrial chemicals

senses.definition: having many industries

examples.en: an industrial city/town
an industrial society
the world’s leading industrial nations

senses.definition: very great in extent or amount

examples.en: They had made industrial quantities of food.

senses.definition: the production of goods from raw materials, especially in factories

examples.en: the needs of British industry
the Department of Trade and Industry

senses.definition: the people and activities involved in producing a particular thing, or in providing a particular service

examples.en: the steel/oil/auto industry
the music/film/tourism industry

industry insiders/analysts/experts
the Kardashian industry (= the large number of people involved in making the Kardashian family successful)

senses.definition: the quality of working hard

examples.en: We were impressed by their industry.

senses.definition: the unfair difference between groups of people in society, when some have more wealth, status or opportunities than others

examples.en: We need to tackle inequality of opportunity wherever we find it.

senses.definition: that you cannot avoid or prevent

senses.definition: happening so often that you always expect it

examples.en: the English and their inevitable cups of tea

senses.definition: something that is certain to happen

examples.en: You have to accept the inevitable.

senses.definition: as is certain to happen

examples.en: Inevitably, the press exaggerated the story.

senses.definition: as you would expect

examples.en: Inevitably, it rained on the day of the wedding.

senses.definition: well known for being bad or evil

examples.en: a general who was infamous for his brutality
the most infamous concentration camp
the infamous British sandwich

senses.definition: a baby or very young child

examples.en: a nursery for infants under two

senses.definition: a child at school between the ages of four and seven

examples.en: The majority of infant teachers are women.
I've known her since we were in the infants (= at infant school).

senses.definition: designed to be used by infants

examples.en: infant formula (= milk for babies)

senses.definition: new and not yet developed

examples.en: infant industries

senses.definition: to make a disease or an illness spread to a person, an animal or a plant

examples.en: It is not possible to infect another person through kissing.

senses.definition: to make a substance contain harmful bacteria that can spread disease

examples.en: The eggs were infected with salmonella.

senses.definition: to make a computer virus spread to another computer or program
to make somebody share a particular feeling

examples.en: She infected the children with her enthusiasm for music.

senses.definition: the act or process of causing or getting a disease

examples.en: to cause/prevent infection

to increase the risk of infection

senses.definition: an illness that is caused by bacteria or a virus and that affects one part of the body

examples.en: an ear/a chest infection
a respiratory infection
a viral/bacterial infection
a media campaign to raise awareness about sexually transmitted infections
to cause an infection
Sneezing is the most common way of spreading an infection.
a fungal infection of the skin

senses.definition: to reach an opinion or decide that something is true on the basis of information that is available

examples.en: Much of the meaning must be inferred from the context.

senses.definition: to suggest indirectly that something is true

to reduce/bring down inflation
a high/low rate of inflation
an inflation rate of 3%

Inflation is currently running at 3%.
rapid/runaway/galloping inflation

senses.definition: a general rise in the level of something that is awarded

senses.definition: the act or process of filling something with air or gas

senses.definition: to make somebody/something suffer something unpleasant

senses.definition: the power that somebody/something has to make somebody/something behave in a particular way

senses.definition: a person or thing that affects the way a person behaves and thinks

examples.en: She draws on her diverse cultural influences to express herself.

There seem to be several influences at work in (= affecting) his writing.

senses.definition: having had too much alcohol to drink

examples.en: She was charged with driving under the influence.
He was arrested for driving under the influence.

senses.definition: to have an effect on the way that somebody behaves or thinks, especially by giving them an example to follow

examples.en: His writings have influenced the lives of millions.

His film is heavily influenced by other film-makers.

senses.definition: to have an effect on a particular situation and the way that it develops

examples.en: A number of social factors influence life expectancy.

senses.definition: having a lot of influence on somebody/something

examples.en: a highly influential book

senses.definition: information

examples.en: For more info, click here.
I couldn't find any contact info for the company.

Let us know if you get any more info.

senses.definition: connected with information

examples.en: an infosheet
We send all potential clients an infopack.

senses.definition: to tell somebody about something, especially in an official way

examples.en: The government took this decision without consulting Parliament or informing the public.

He went to inform them of his decision.

I am pleased to inform you that you have won first prize in this month’s competition.

I have not been informed when the ceremony will take place.
Inform me at once if there are any changes in her condition.

senses.definition: to find out information about something

examples.en: We need time to inform ourselves thoroughly of the problem.

senses.definition: to have an influence on something

examples.en: Religion informs every aspect of their lives.
These guidelines will be used to inform any future decisions.

senses.definition: relaxed and friendly; not following strict rules of how to behave or do something

examples.en: an informal atmosphere
an informal meeting/gathering/visit
an informal arrangement
informal discussions/talks
an informal chat/conversation

senses.definition: suitable for normal conversation and writing to friends rather than for serious speech and letters

examples.en: an informal expression

senses.definition: suitable for wearing at home or when relaxing rather than for a special or an official occasion

examples.en: I changed into more informal clothes.
Dress is informal, and storage space often limited, so you’ll be more comfortable travelling light.

senses.definition: done by individuals on a small scale, especially unofficially or illegally

examples.en: the informal economy/sector
informal street traders
The city has acted to remove informal traders from train stations.

variants.html: (also informal info)

senses.definition: facts or details about somebody/something

examples.en: a piece of information
What was your main source of information for your article?
The documents contain confidential personal information.

He refused to comment before he had seen all the relevant information.
We will need a little more background information.
to collect/gather/obtain/receive information
to give/share/pass on information
Your local council can provide information on sports facilities in your area.
For more information about the project, click on the link below.

For further information on this property, please visit our website.
