senses.definition: a phone service that you can use to find out a person's phone number
data that is processed, stored or sent by a computer

examples.en: Algorithms are essential to the way computers process information.

senses.definition: what is represented by a particular arrangement or sequence of things

examples.en: the transfer of genetic information from DNA to RNA

senses.definition: written on documents that are sent to somebody who needs to know the information in them but does not need to deal with them

examples.en: This letter is for information only.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that they are wrong about something

examples.en: For your information, I don't even have a car.

senses.definition: a person, book, etc. that can give you a lot of information on a particular subject

examples.en: This book is a mine of information on the Romans.

senses.definition: the basic systems and services that are necessary for a country or an organization to run smoothly, for example buildings, transport and water and power supplies
one of the things from which something is made, especially one of the foods that are used together to make a particular dish

examples.en: Mix all the ingredients in a bowl.
Our skin cream contains only natural ingredients.
The only active ingredient in this medicine is aspirin.

senses.definition: one of the things or qualities that are necessary to make something successful

examples.en: It has all the ingredients of a good mystery story.

senses.definition: a person or an animal that lives in a particular place

examples.en: the oldest inhabitant of the village

senses.definition: that is a basic or permanent part of somebody/something and that cannot be removed

senses.definition: to receive money, property, etc. from somebody when they die

senses.definition: to have qualities, physical features, etc. that are similar to those of your parents, grandparents, etc.

senses.definition: to prevent something from happening or make it happen more slowly or less frequently than normal

senses.definition: to explain something to somebody and/or make them experience it for the first time

senses.definition: to make somebody a member of a particular group, especially as part of a secret ceremony

senses.definition: a person who has been allowed to join a particular group, organization, or religion and is learning its rules and secrets

senses.definition: the ability to decide and act on your own without waiting for somebody to tell you what to do

senses.definition: an act of forcing a liquid or other substance into something

senses.definition: upset or offended because something unfair has been done

senses.definition: introducing or using new ideas, ways of doing something, etc.

senses.definition: an official process to find out the cause of something or to find out information about something

senses.definition: to exist between two events or places

senses.definition: action taken to improve or help a situation

examples.en: calls for government intervention to save the steel industry
In the second group of states, direct intervention in the economy was limited.

senses.definition: action by a country to become involved in the affairs of another country when they have not been asked to do so

examples.en: armed/military intervention
NATO intervention in the troubled region

senses.definition: action taken to improve a medical condition or illness

examples.en: a medical/surgical intervention
Most patients make a recovery without further intervention.

senses.definition: the act of interrupting somebody when they are speaking in order to say something

examples.en: People resented his repeated interventions in the debate.

senses.definition: an occasion when a group of people meet to take action with a friend or family member who has an addiction to drugs or alcohol, in order to help them recover

examples.en: Her daughters staged an intervention.
Family intervention is an essential component of treatment for adolescent drug abuse.

senses.definition: a formal meeting at which somebody is asked questions to see if they are suitable for a particular job, or for a course of study at a college, university, etc.

examples.en: a job interview
She's been called for (an) interview.
He has an interview next week for the manager's job.
I got an interview with a PR company for a trainee position.
In the interview they asked me about my future plans.
He came across very well at the interview.

senses.definition: a meeting (often a public one) at which a journalist asks somebody questions in order to find out their opinions

examples.en: a television/TV/radio/newspaper interview
to do/give an interview (= to agree to answer questions)
to conduct an interview (= to ask somebody questions in public)
The interview was published in all the papers.
Yesterday, in an interview on German television, the minister denied the reports.
an in-depth interview with the new governor
an exclusive interview about her new book
The film begins with an interview by two local student reporters.

senses.definition: a private meeting between people when questions are asked and answered

examples.en: a telephone/phone interview
She's had an interview with the careers adviser.
He gave a very full account in long interviews with experienced police officers.
Interviews and questionnaires are the most important tools in market research.

senses.definition: to talk to somebody and ask them questions at a formal meeting to find out if they are suitable for a job, course of study, etc.

examples.en: The university interviews all potential candidates.
Which post are you being interviewed for?
We interviewed ten people for the job.
The deadline for applications is 15 October and we will be interviewing early in November.

senses.definition: to talk to somebody and answer questions at a formal meeting to get a job, a place on a course of study, etc.

examples.en: The website gives you tips on interviewing for colleges.
If you don't interview well you are unlikely to get the job.

senses.definition: to ask somebody questions about their life, opinions, etc., especially on the radio or television or for a newspaper or magazine

examples.en: Next week, I will be interviewing Spielberg about his latest movie.
The prime minister declined to be interviewed.
I heard her being interviewed on the news earlier.

senses.definition: to ask somebody questions at a private meeting

examples.en: The police are waiting to interview the injured man.
After 14 days, patients were interviewed about the recurrence of any symptoms.

senses.definition: having a close and friendly relationship

examples.en: intimate friends
We're not on intimate terms with our neighbours.

senses.definition: private and personal, often in a sexual way

examples.en: The article revealed intimate details about his family life.
the most intimate parts of the body

senses.definition: encouraging close, friendly relationships, sometimes of a sexual nature

examples.en: an intimate restaurant
He knew an intimate little cafe where they would not be disturbed.

senses.definition: very detailed

examples.en: an intimate knowledge of the English countryside

senses.definition: very close

examples.en: an intimate connection between class and educational success

senses.definition: having a sexual relationship with somebody
to let somebody know what you think or mean
synonyms: let it be known/make it known that…

examples.en: He has already intimated to us his intention to retire.
He has already intimated (that) he intends to retire.

senses.definition: a close personal friend

examples.en: He was a wartime minister and intimate of Churchill.

senses.definition: to a position in or inside something

examples.en: Come into the house.
She dived into the water.
He threw the letter into the fire.
She turned and walked off into the night.

senses.definition: in the direction of something

examples.en: Speak clearly into the microphone.
Driving into the sun, we had to shade our eyes.

senses.definition: to a point at which you hit somebody/something

examples.en: The truck crashed into a parked car.

senses.definition: to a point during a period of time

examples.en: She carried on working late into the night.
He didn't get married until he was well into his forties.

senses.definition: used to show a change in state

examples.en: The fruit can be made into jam.
Can you translate this passage into German?
They came into power in 2023.
She was sliding into depression.

senses.definition: used to show the result of an action

examples.en: He was shocked into a confession of guilt.

senses.definition: about or in connection with something

examples.en: an inquiry into safety procedures

senses.definition: used when you are dividing numbers

examples.en: 3 into 24 is 8.

senses.definition: to be interested in something in an active way

examples.en: He's into surfing in a big way.

senses.definition: to owe somebody money or be owed money by somebody

examples.en: By the time he'd fixed the leak, I was into him for $500.
The bank was into her for $100 000.

senses.definition: very interesting because of being unusual or not having an obvious answer

examples.en: These discoveries raise intriguing questions.
an intriguing possibility
He found her intriguing.
It all sounds very intriguing.

senses.definition: to tell two or more people who have not met before what each other’s names are; to tell somebody what your name is

examples.en: Allow me to introduce my mother.
The lead singer introduced each member of the band.
He introduced me as a new member of the company.
He introduced me to a Greek girl at the party.

examples.cf: introduce A to B as something
examples.en: She was introduced to me as a well-known novelist.
Sue and Jo were introduced by a mutual friend.
We have met before, but we haven't been formally introduced.
Can I introduce myself? I'm Helen Robins.
The chairperson introduced herself and opened the discussion.
‘Kay, this is Steve.’ ‘Yes, I know—we've already introduced ourselves.’
She made sure she introduced herself to all her new colleagues.

senses.definition: to be the main speaker in a television or radio show, who gives details about the show and who presents the people who are in it; to tell the audience the name of the person who is going to speak or perform

examples.en: The next programme will be introduced by Mary David.
It is my pleasure to introduce my first guest on the show tonight…

senses.definition: to mention something for the first time in a piece of writing

examples.en: Introduce the topic and briefly state your own opinion.
Each new idea should be introduced in a new paragraph.
In Chapter 3 the author introduces the concept of the learner-centred classroom to readers.

senses.definition: to make somebody learn about something or do something for the first time

examples.en: The first lecture introduces students to the main topics of the course.
A neighbour of his introduced him to the world of Brazilian capoeira.
She has developed her love of archery since being introduced to the sport by a workmate.
It was she who first introduced the pleasures of sailing to me.

senses.definition: to make something available for use, discussion, etc. for the first time

examples.en: The company has recently introduced a new warehouse management system.
Legislation will be introduced to ban the sale of these products to children.
The new law was introduced in 2021.
Psychologists first introduced the term in the early 1990s.
to introduce measures/reforms
We are going to introduce a few changes to the system.
The government plans to gradually introduce the latest technology into all schools.

senses.definition: to be the start of something new

examples.en: Bands from London introduced the craze for this kind of music.
A slow theme introduces the first movement.

senses.definition: to bring a plant, an animal or a disease to a place for the first time

examples.en: Some new species were introduced accidentally to Australia from Europe.
Vegetation patterns changed when goats were introduced to the island.
Diseases were inadvertently introduced into the environment by settlers.

senses.definition: to formally present a new law so that it can be discussed

examples.en: to introduce a bill (before Parliament)

senses.definition: to put something into something

examples.en: Particles of glass had been introduced into the baby food.

senses.definition: to cause something to contain errors

examples.en: Measurement error could have been introduced by respondents' recall errors.
The analyst's rankings rely on subjective information, which may introduce a bias into the rankings.

senses.definition: the first part of a book or speech that gives a general idea of what is to follow

examples.en: a book with an excellent introduction and notes
Can you write a brief introduction to the text?
The English edition has an introduction by Herbert Read.
His mother is mentioned in the introduction.
By way of introduction, let me give you the background to the story.

senses.definition: the act of making one person formally known to another or a group of others, in which you tell them the person's name

examples.en: Introductions were made and the conversation started to flow.
Our speaker today needs no introduction (= is already well known).
I was hoping to get an introduction to his good-looking colleague.
a letter of introduction (= a letter which tells somebody who you are, written by somebody who knows both you and the person reading the letter)

senses.definition: the act of bringing something into use or existence for the first time, or of bringing something to a place for the first time

examples.en: the introduction of new manufacturing methods
the introduction of compulsory military service
the 1 000th anniversary of the introduction of Christianity to Russia
We can now begin commercial introduction of the product into the United States.

senses.definition: a thing that is brought into use or introduced to a place for the first time

examples.en: The book lists plants suitable for the British flower garden, among them many new introductions.

senses.definition: a person’s first experience of something

examples.en: This album was my first introduction to modern jazz.

senses.definition: a book or course for people beginning to study a subject

examples.en: ‘Global Politics: An Introduction’
It's a useful introduction to an extremely complex subject.
‘An Introduction to Astronomy’
The course provides a brief introduction to philosophy.

senses.definition: a short section at the beginning of a piece of music

examples.en: an eight-bar introduction
After a lengthy musical introduction, the dancers finally appear.

senses.definition: to enter a country, town, etc. using military force in order to take control of it

examples.en: Troops invaded on August 9th that year.
When did the Romans invade Britain?

senses.definition: to enter a place in large numbers, especially in a way that causes damage or problems

examples.en: Demonstrators invaded the government buildings.
As the final whistle blew, fans began invading the pitch.
The cancer cells may invade other parts of the body.

senses.definition: to affect something in an unpleasant or annoying way

examples.en: Do the press have the right to invade her privacy in this way?
You feel tense with worrying thoughts constantly invading your sleep.

senses.definition: the act of an army entering another country by force in order to take control of it

examples.en: the German invasion of Poland in 1939
the threat of invasion
an invasion force/fleet

senses.definition: the fact of a large number of people or things arriving somewhere, especially people or things that are unpleasant

examples.en: the annual tourist invasion
Farmers are struggling to cope with an invasion of slugs.
Robberies and home invasions are grim facts of daily life.

senses.definition: an act or a process that affects somebody/something in a way that is not welcome

examples.en: The singer described the photographs of her as an invasion of privacy.

senses.definition: to produce or design something that has not existed before

examples.en: Who invented the steam engine?
I wish mobile phones had never been invented!
The term ‘sociology’ was invented by Auguste Comte.

senses.definition: to say or describe something that is not true, especially in order to trick people

examples.en: What excuse did he invent this time?
Many children invent an imaginary friend.

senses.definition: a thing or an idea that has been invented

examples.en: Fax machines were a wonderful invention at the time.
He failed to patent his invention and never made a penny from it.

senses.definition: the act of inventing something

examples.en: Such changes have not been seen since the invention of the printing press.
After the war, Westinghouse devoted himself to invention.

senses.definition: the act of inventing a story or an idea and pretending that it is true; a story invented in this way

examples.en: This story is apparently a complete invention.
Most of what she says is pure invention.
What would he tell his parents? Some invention and quick thinking—that’s what was needed.

senses.definition: the ability to have new and interesting ideas

examples.en: John was full of invention—always making up new dance steps and sequences.
Her powers of invention were somewhat limited.

idioms.word: necessity is the mother of invention

senses.definition: a difficult new problem forces people to think of a solution to it
to buy property, shares in a company, etc. in the hope of making a profit

examples.en: Now is a good time to invest.
She advised us to invest in the property market.
If you want to invest your money, you are probably better off with bonds.
He invested his life savings in his daughter's business.
She personally invested $980 000 in the company.

senses.definition: to spend money on something in order to make it better or more successful

examples.en: The company plans to invest still further.
The government has invested heavily in public transport.
The industry has failed to invest in new product development.
Tokyo instead invested on infrastructure.
The rest of the required funds will be invested by the council.
The college is to invest $2 million in a new conference hall.
In his time managing the club he has invested millions on new players.

senses.definition: to spend time, energy, effort, etc. on something that you think is good or useful

examples.en: She had invested all her adult life in the relationship.
He had invested so much personal energy turning the company around.
Are you willing to invest the time and effort necessary to make the scheme work?

senses.definition: to give somebody power or authority, especially as part of their job

examples.en: The new position invested her with a good deal of responsibility.
The interview was broadcast on the same day he was invested as President.

senses.definition: to carefully examine the facts of a situation, an event, a crime, etc. to find out the truth about it or how it happened

examples.en: The FBI has been called in to investigate.
the senior investigating officer
‘What was that noise?’ ‘I'll go and investigate.’
Detectives are currently investigating possible links between the murders.
to investigate a crime/a complaint/an incident
The allegations have not yet been thoroughly investigated.
The report calls for a commission to investigate the matter further.
The case will be investigated in detail to determine whether the claims are true.
Police are investigating what happened.

senses.definition: to try to find out information about somebody’s character, activities, etc.

examples.en: This is not the first time he has been investigated by the police for fraud.
She is being investigated over allegations of illegal business dealings.
They were investigated on suspicion of drug smuggling.

senses.definition: to find out information and facts about a subject or problem by study or research

examples.en: The study investigates the effects of feeding a high-energy diet to cows.
Researchers are investigating how foreign speakers gain fluency.

senses.definition: an official examination of the facts about a situation, crime, etc.

examples.en: a criminal/murder/police investigation
an accident investigation team
The president has promised a full investigation.
The authorities have launched an investigation to determine why the ferry sank.
She remains under investigation for fraud.
He is under investigation for assaulting a teenager.
The police are conducting ongoing investigations into the man's death.
Officials are calling for an investigation into the incident.
On investigation, the noise turned out to be only a door banging.
He is suspended pending a thorough investigation (= until an investigation has happened) of the allegations.

senses.definition: a scientific or academic examination of the facts of a subject or problem

examples.en: Further investigation revealed a flaw in this theory.
Refer patients with these symptoms for further investigation.
the results of a preliminary investigation into stress at work

senses.definition: a person who examines a situation such as an accident or a crime to find out the truth

examples.en: air safety investigators
a private investigator (= a detective)

senses.definition: the act of investing money in something

examples.en: foreign/private investment
capital/business/property investment
to attract/encourage investment
This country needs investment in education.
This initiative involves considerable long-term investment by the university.
an investment trust/fund/firm
an investment adviser
investment opportunities/decisions/strategies

senses.definition: the money that you invest, or the thing that you invest in

examples.en: a minimum investment of $10 000
a substantial/significant/major investment
Our investments are not doing well.
We bought the house as an investment (= to make money).
The area is trying to attract £11 million of private investment to stimulate the local economy.
a high return on investment
investment returns/income
Bonds should be part of your investment portfolio.

senses.definition: a thing that is worth buying because it will be useful or helpful

examples.en: A microwave is a good investment.

senses.definition: the act of giving time or effort to a particular task in order to make it successful

examples.en: The project has demanded considerable investment of time and effort.
parents' emotional investment in their children

senses.definition: a person or an organization that invests money in something

examples.en: small investors (= private people)
institutional investors

senses.definition: that cannot be seen

examples.en: a wizard who could make himself invisible
She felt invisible in the crowd.
stars invisible to the naked eye

senses.definition: ignored or treated as if they/it cannot be seen

examples.en: Homeless people feel that they are invisible.
It's interesting how women are rendered invisible in these statistics.

senses.definition: connected with a service that a country provides, such as banks or tourism, rather than goods

examples.en: invisible earnings

senses.definition: a spoken or written request to somebody to do something or to go somewhere

examples.en: to issue/extend an invitation
to accept/turn down/decline an invitation
I received an invitation to the party
She repeated her invitation for dinner at her place.
We got a wedding invitation from Alex and Chris.
I have an open invitation (= not restricted to a particular date) to visit my friend in Japan.

senses.definition: the act of inviting somebody or of being invited

examples.en: He produced an official letter of invitation.
Admission is by invitation only.
A concert was held at the invitation of the mayor.

senses.definition: a card or piece of paper that you use to invite somebody to something

examples.en: We've already sent out the invitations.
Have you ordered the wedding invitations yet?

senses.definition: something that encourages somebody to do something or encourages something to happen, usually something bad

examples.en: Leaving the doors unlocked is an open invitation to burglars.
Putting the kids in charge was an invitation to disaster.

senses.definition: to ask somebody to come to a social event

examples.en: Have you been invited to their party?
She very kindly invited me to lunch.
I'd have liked to have gone but I wasn't invited.
My mother invited a few friends that she hadn't seen for 20 years.
Let's invite them all for dinner.
They have invited me to go to Paris with them.

senses.definition: to ask somebody formally to go somewhere or do something; to make a formal or polite request for something

examples.en: The bishop invited representatives from all the parishes in the diocese.
Successful candidates will be invited for interview next week.
Clarke was not invited to the meeting.
The ministry had invited tenders for the demolition of the buildings.
He invited questions from the audience.
Readers are invited to email their comments to us.
He was invited to attend the Paris Peace Conference in 1919.
Audience members are invited to participate in the discussion.
In 1956 she was invited to join the Bolshoi Ballet as a soloist.

senses.definition: to make something, especially something bad or unpleasant, likely to happen

examples.en: Such comments are just inviting trouble.
Such harsh punishments invited prisoners to respond with defiance.

senses.definition: an invitation

examples.en: Thanks for your invite.

senses.definition: to mention or use a law, rule, etc. as a reason for doing something

examples.en: It is unlikely that libel laws will be invoked.

senses.definition: to mention a person, a theory, an example, etc. to support your opinions or ideas, or as a reason for something

examples.en: She invoked several eminent scholars to back up her argument.

senses.definition: to mention somebody’s name to make people feel a particular thing or act in a particular way

examples.en: His name was invoked as a symbol of the revolution.

senses.definition: to make a request (for help) to somebody, especially a god
to make somebody have a particular feeling or imagine a particular scene

examples.en: The opening paragraph invokes a vision of England in the early Middle Ages.

senses.definition: to begin to run a program, etc.

examples.en: This command will invoke the HELP system.

senses.definition: to make evil appear by using magic
if a situation, an event or an activity involves something, that thing is an important or necessary part or result of it

examples.en: Any investment involves an element of risk.
The process involves using steam to sterilize the instruments.
The test will involve answering questions about a photograph.
The job involves me travelling all over the country.
The job involves my travelling all over the country.

senses.definition: if a situation, an event or an activity involves somebody/something, they take part in it or are affected by it

examples.en: There was a serious incident involving a group of youths.
cases involving the care of young children

senses.definition: to make somebody take part in something

examples.en: We want to involve as many people as possible in the celebrations.
Parents should involve themselves in their child's education.

senses.definition: to say or do something to show that somebody took part in something, especially a crime

examples.en: His confession involved a number of other politicians in the affair.

senses.definition: taking part in something; being part of something or connected with something

examples.en: Some people tried to stop the fight but I didn't want to get involved.
It can be helpful to talk about your worries to someone who is not directly involved.
He became actively involved in politics.
How many vehicles were involved in the crash?
They were involved in a road accident.
Several people have been involved with the project from the beginning.
We'll make our decision and contact the people involved.

senses.definition: giving a lot of time or attention to somebody/something

examples.en: She was deeply involved with the local hospital.
You're too emotionally involved with the situation.
You shouldn't allow yourself to become so heavily involved.
He's a very involved father (= he spends a lot of time with his children).
I was so involved in my book I didn't hear you knock.

senses.definition: having a close personal relationship with somebody

examples.en: They're not romantically involved.
She became personally involved with her boss.

senses.definition: complicated and difficult to understand

examples.en: an involved plot

senses.definition: the act of taking part in something or dealing with somebody

examples.en: US involvement in European wars
When she was promoted, she missed the day-to-day involvement with customers.

senses.definition: the act of giving a lot of time and attention to something you care about

examples.en: The new album came out of her growing involvement with contemporary music.
the involvement of parents in their children's education

senses.definition: a close relationship with somebody, especially a romantic or sexual relationship with somebody that you are not married to

examples.en: He spoke openly about his involvement with the singer.
Nurses usually try to avoid emotional involvement with patients.
Her husband's involvement with another woman led to their divorce.

senses.definition: a chemical element. Iron is a hard strong metal that is used to make steel and is also found in small quantities in blood and food.

examples.en: iron gates/bars/railings
a hut with a corrugated iron roof
the iron and steel industries
iron ore (= rock containing iron)
foods that are rich in iron
patients with iron deficiency (= not enough iron in their blood)
iron tablets (= containing iron prepared as a medicine)
She had a will of iron (= it was very strong).

senses.definition: a tool with a flat metal base that can be heated and used to make clothes smooth

examples.en: a steam iron

senses.definition: a tool made of iron or another metal
chains or other heavy objects made of iron, attached to the arms and legs of prisoners, especially in the past

examples.en: leg irons
to clap somebody in irons

senses.definition: one of the set of clubs (= sticks for hitting the ball with) that have a metal head

examples.en: He hit a magnificent shot with a nine iron.

idioms.word: have several, etc. irons in the fire

senses.definition: to be involved in several activities or areas of business at the same time, hoping that at least one will be successful
to do exercises in which you lift heavy weights in order to make your muscles stronger

idioms.word: rule (somebody/something) with a rod of iron

senses.definition: to control a person or a group of people very severely

idioms.word: strike while the iron is hot

senses.definition: to make use of an opportunity immediately
to make clothes, etc. smooth by using an iron

examples.en: He was ironing when I arrived.
I'll need to iron that dress before I can wear it.

senses.definition: very strong and determined

examples.en: She was known as the ‘Iron Lady’.
a man of iron will

idioms.word: an iron fist/hand (in a velvet glove)

senses.definition: if you use the words an iron fist/hand when describing the way that somebody behaves, you mean that they treat people severely. This treatment may be hidden behind a kind appearance (the velvet glove).

examples.en: They promised that the army would strike with an iron fist at any resistance.
The iron hand in the velvet glove approach seems to work best with this age group.

variants.html:
(also less frequent ironical
 
/aɪˈrɒnɪkl/
 
/aɪˈrɑːnɪkl/
)

senses.definition: showing that you really mean the opposite of what you are saying; expressing irony

examples.en: an ironic comment

senses.definition: strange or funny because it is very different from what you expect

examples.en: It's ironic that she became a teacher—she used to hate school.

senses.definition: in a way that shows that you really mean the opposite of what you are saying; in a way that expresses irony

examples.en: He smiled ironically.

senses.definition: in a way that is strange or funny because it is very different from what you expect

examples.en: Ironically, the book she felt was her worst sold more copies than any of her others.

senses.definition: the funny or strange aspect of a situation that is very different from what you expect; a situation like this

examples.en: It was one of life's little ironies.
The irony is that when he finally got the job, he discovered he didn't like it.

senses.definition: the use of words that say the opposite of what you really mean, often as a joke and with a tone of voice that shows this

examples.en: ‘England is famous for its food,’ she said with heavy irony.
There was a note of irony in his voice.
She said it without a hint/trace of irony.

senses.definition: not important to or connected with a situation

examples.en: totally/completely/largely irrelevant
irrelevant remarks
Whether I believe you or not is irrelevant now.
That evidence is irrelevant to the case.
Many people consider politics irrelevant to their lives.

variants.html: (abbreviation I, I., Is.)

senses.definition: a piece of land that is completely surrounded by water

examples.en: a small/tiny island
a remote island off the coast of Scotland
the islands in the Baltic Sea
the Virgin Islands
the resort island of Bali
We spent a week on the Greek island of Kos.
an island nation/state
No place on the planet can remain an island of affluence in a sea of suffering.

variants.text: (also refuge (British English), traffic island British and North American English)
variants.html: (also refuge (British English), traffic island British and North American English)

senses.definition: an area in the middle of a road where you can stand and wait for cars to go past until it is safe for you to cross
a kitchen unit with a worktop (= a flat surface for preparing food on), placed in the middle of the room with access from all sides

examples.en: Their kitchen is huge, with an island and space for a small dining area.

senses.definition: to separate somebody/something physically or socially from other people or things

examples.en: Patients with the disease should be isolated.

He was immediately isolated from the other prisoners.
This decision will isolate the country from the rest of Europe.

senses.definition: to separate a part of a situation, problem, idea, etc. so that you can see what it is and deal with it separately

examples.en: It is possible to isolate a number of factors that contributed to her downfall.

senses.definition: to separate a single substance, cell, etc. from others so that you can study it

examples.en: Researchers are still trying to isolate the gene that causes this abnormality.

senses.definition: far away from any others

examples.en: isolated rural areas

senses.definition: without much contact with other people or other countries

examples.en: I felt very isolated in my new job.
Elderly people easily become socially isolated.
The decision left the country isolated from its allies.

senses.definition: single; happening once

examples.en: The police said the attack was an isolated incident.

senses.definition: the act of separating somebody/something; the state of being separate

examples.en: geographical isolation
an isolation hospital/ward (= for people with infectious diseases)
The country has been threatened with complete isolation from the international community unless the atrocities stop.
He lives in splendid isolation (= far from, or in a superior position to, everyone else).
the isolation of the polio virus

senses.definition: the state of being alone or lonely

examples.en: Many unemployed people experience feelings of isolation and depression.

senses.definition: separately; alone

examples.en: To make sense, these figures should not be looked at in isolation.
Words are pronounced differently in isolation from how they are pronounced in context.

senses.definition: an important topic that people are discussing or arguing about

examples.en: a key/major issue
This is a big issue; we need more time to think about it.
Teacher education has become a political issue.
They discussed a number of important environmental issues.
They are talking about issues relating to the safety of children online.
Her work deals with issues of race and identity.
to explore/debate/examine an issue
The union plans to raise the issue of overtime.
We really need to focus on the key issues and not get sidetracked.
You're just avoiding the issue.
Don't confuse the issue.
The meeting included discussion of a range of issues.
What you say is interesting, but it does not affect the question at issue here.

senses.definition: a problem or worry that somebody has with something

examples.en: If you have any issues, please call this number.
The community is working together to address social issues and problems.
All technical issues have now been resolved.
Miller decided to tackle the issue head on.
Serious issues arose during the development of the new product.
Money is not an issue.
I'm not bothered about the cost—you're the one who's making it an issue.
She's always on a diet—she has issues about food.
Young people sometimes struggle with issues around body image.
He still has some issues with women (= has some problems dealing with them).

senses.definition: one of a regular series of magazines or newspapers

examples.en: the July issue of ‘What Car?’
The article appeared in issue 25.
an article in the current issue of ‘Newsweek’

senses.definition: a number or set of things that are supplied and made available at the same time

examples.en: The company is planning a new share issue.
a special issue of stamps

senses.definition: the act of supplying or making available things for people to buy or use

examples.en: I bought a set of the new stamps on the date of issue.
the issue of blankets to the refugees

senses.definition: the act of formally making something known to people

examples.en: the issue of a joint statement by the French and German foreign ministers

senses.definition: children of your own

examples.en: He died without issue.

senses.definition: to be the most important part of the subject that is being discussed

examples.en: What is at issue is whether she was responsible for her actions.

senses.definition: to do something to make people take a decision quickly
to start disagreeing or arguing with somebody about something

examples.en: I must take issue with you on that point.

senses.definition: to make something known formally

examples.en: They issued a joint statement denying the charges.
to issue an apology
a report issued by the Department for Education
A warning was issued yesterday by the government, asking people to stay in their homes.
The president has the authority to issue orders to the military.
The new guidelines have been issued to all doctors.

senses.definition: to give something to somebody, especially officially

examples.en: to issue a licence/certificate/permit/ticket
The authorities refused to issue him a visa.
New members will be issued with a temporary identity card.
Work permits were issued to only 5% of those who applied for them.

senses.definition: to start a legal process against somebody, especially by means of an official document

examples.en: to issue a writ against somebody
A warrant has been issued for his arrest.

senses.definition: to produce something such as a magazine, article, etc.

examples.en: We issue a monthly newsletter.

senses.definition: to produce new stamps, coins, shares, etc. for sale to the public

examples.en: They issued a special set of stamps to mark the occasion.
newly issued banknotes

senses.definition: one thing on a list of things to buy, do, talk about, etc.

examples.en: What's the next item on the agenda?
There are plenty of vegetarian items on the menu.
She still has five items on her to-do list.
Students had to select three topics from the list of items.
There is a maximum score of two points per test item.

senses.definition: a single object or thing

examples.en: Can I pay for each item separately?
The price of many basic food items continues to rise.
household items such as brushes and bedclothes
A windproof jacket is an essential item of clothing for hillwalking.
Are there any items of furniture you want to take with you?
The computer was my largest single item of expenditure.
This clock is a collector's item (= because it is rare and valuable).

senses.definition: a single piece of news in a newspaper, on television, online, etc.

examples.en: The following news item may be of interest to you.
I heard an item on the radio about a new cancer treatment.
I came across two items of disturbing news.
The Journal is packed with items of interest from cover to cover.

senses.definition: to be involved in a romantic or sexual relationship

examples.en: Are they an item?

senses.definition: used when the animal or thing that does an action is also affected by it

examples.en: The cat was washing itself.
Does the computer turn itself off?
The company has got itself into difficulties.
There's every reason for the team to feel proud of itself.

senses.definition: used to emphasize an animal, a thing, etc.

examples.en: The village itself is pretty, but the surrounding countryside is rather dull.

idioms.word: be patience, honesty, simplicity, etc. itself

senses.definition: to be an example of complete patience, etc.

examples.en: The manager of the hotel was courtesy itself.

senses.definition: automatically; without anyone doing anything

examples.en: The machine will start by itself in a few seconds.

senses.definition: alone

examples.en: The house stands by itself in an acre of land.

senses.definition: considered separately from other things; in its true nature

examples.en: In itself, it's not a difficult problem to solve.

senses.definition: for only it to have or use; not shared with others

examples.en: The company doesn't have the market to itself.
